width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">What is the title of the Op-Ed?</span></td><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\"><strong>Town Music Shop Blows the Horn on Needed Music Education</strong></span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">Who is the author?</span></td><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">Henry Schwinkle</span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">Why is the author writing?</span></td><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">He wants to convince readers that music should be taught in schools.&nbsp; He also wants readers to come to an information session.</span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">Who will read it?</span></td><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">Residents of your town</span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">What is it about?&nbsp; What is the topic?</span></td><td><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">not filled in</span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">What does the author think about the topic? </span></td><td><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">not filled in</span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">What support does the author use to prove or explain his ideas?</span></td><td><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">not filled in</span></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"ju-small-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:14px;\">How does the author conclude the Op-Ed?</span></td><td><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">not filled in</span></td></tr></tbody></table>","headerText":"What is this all about?"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"3"},"leftText":"<p>Your next step is to identify the author&#39;s <strong>main idea</strong>.<br /><br />The main idea is made up of two parts: the topic and what the author thinks about the topic.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Main idea:</span></p><p><strong>Topic</strong> + <strong>What the author thinks about it</strong></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"4"},"leftText":"<p>To find the main idea read the entire article.&nbsp;&nbsp; Using the active reading strategy of questioning, ask yourself two questions:<br /><br />1.&nbsp; <em>What is this all about?</em>&nbsp; This is the <strong>topic</strong>.<br /><br />2.&nbsp; <em>What does the author think about the topic?</em><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"5"},"leftText":"<p>You begin to read the first paragraph, asking yourself, <em>What is this all about?</em><br /><br />Try to answer your question in a single sentence or two.<br /><br />Do not include details.&nbsp; They are part of the paragraph, but not a part of the main idea.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" height=\"359\" style=\"width: 100%;\" width=\"363\"><tbody><tr><td><p>. . .(March 3, 2016) The recent unfortunate incident in our town has created speculation about ways to keep our children out of trouble.&nbsp; The case of Tina Tully (also known as Tiny) remains fresh in the minds of all residents.&nbsp; Tina Tully, eight years old, was recently accused of a series of thefts of musical instruments.&nbsp; When local police eventually caught Tina in the act, she confessed, explaining that she was only &ldquo;borrowing&rdquo; one instrument at a time.&nbsp; It happens that she longed to play an instrument, but was not sure which one to choose.&nbsp; So, during a period of several days she sampled a number of musical possibilities, somehow avoiding detection by the staff. She eventually settled on the tuba.&nbsp; When questioned, Tina expressed sadness that her three older brothers had been given access to music lessons while in the local schools.&nbsp; Budget cuts forced the elimination of music programs, so Tina took matters into her own hands.&nbsp; What&rsquo;s a music store owner and police chief to do?&nbsp; That&rsquo;s easy: Tina was forgiven and will perform community service at Tooters weekly for the next three months.&nbsp; Best of all, the store has donated a tuba rental and music lessons to Tina.&nbsp; Happy ending? Not so fast. . .</p></td></tr></tbody></table>","headerText":""},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"6"},"leftText":"<p>You answer the question, <em>What is the first paragraph all about?</em>&nbsp; in your own words.&nbsp;<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">In your own words:</span></p><p>A small girl, Tina Tully, stole and used several musical instruments over a period of several days. When she was caught, she told police she wanted to play an instrument, but was not given any opportunity to do so&nbsp; in the local schools.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"7"},"leftText":"<p>You wonder if this is the topic of the whole article.&nbsp; Ask yourself, <em>Is this article about Tina Tully and her desire to play a musical instrument?</em><br /><br />You continue reading to see if the author introduces another topic.<br /><br />You read the next paragraph.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>. . .The day the music died&mdash;we have lost something.&nbsp; </strong>It is not difficult to establish a connection between this incident and the loss of music programs in our schools.&nbsp; Prior to 2012, students enjoyed many opportunities to participate in music activities, including weekly music class from a certified teacher; optional, free lessons on an instrument of their choice; affordable rentals with an option to buy the instrument; and joining the chorus, a performance orchestra, the marching band, or small, select instrumental groups.&nbsp;&nbsp; Students also could receive counseling and advice offered by music professionals at all schools in our city.&nbsp; Few people are aware that when it was decided to cut a program, the choice was either drama or music.&nbsp; The music program took the hit for the team.&nbsp; We need to bring music back to the schools. . .</p></td></tr></tbody></table>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"8"},"rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">In your own words:</span></p><p>Music programs in our schools have been cut.</p>","leftText":"<p>After reading this paragraph, you realize that Henry Schwinkle has used Tina Tully&#39;s story to interest readers in his topic.<br /><br />The topic he is really writing about is the lack of music education in the schools in your town.<br /><br />You summarize this in your own words.<br />&nbsp;</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"9"},"leftText":"<p>Add the information about the topic to your organizer.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"marker\">What is it about?&nbsp; What is the topic?</span></td><td><span class=\"marker\">Music programs in schools have been cut.</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Organizerwithtopic.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=no,width=800,left=100,height=720,top=50'); return false;\">View the complete Op-Ed organizer <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">(opens in a new window)</span></a>&nbsp;</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"10"},"leftText":"<p>To identify the main idea, you still need to know what the author thinks about the topic.<br /><br />You know that the topic is that music programs in the schools in town have been cut.<br /><br />Re-read the second paragraph, and ask yourself, <em>What does the author think about this topic?</em><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>. . .The day the music died&mdash;we have lost something.&nbsp; </strong>It is not difficult to establish a connection between this incident and the loss of music programs in our schools.&nbsp; Prior to 2012, students enjoyed many opportunities to participate in music activities, including weekly music class from a certified teacher; optional, free lessons on an instrument of their choice; affordable rentals with an option to buy the instrument; and joining the chorus, a performance orchestra, the marching band, or small, select instrumental groups.&nbsp;&nbsp; Students also could receive counseling and advice offered by music professionals at all schools in our city.&nbsp; Few people are aware that when it was decided to cut a program, the choice was either drama or music.&nbsp; The music program took the hit for the team.&nbsp; We need to bring music back to the schools. . .</p></td></tr></tbody></table>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"11"},"leftText":"<p>The last sentence of this paragraph lets you know what the author thinks:<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;\">We need to bring music back to the schools.</span><br /><br />You put this in your own words.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\"><strong>In your own words:</strong></span></p><p>The author believes that we should start teaching music in the schools again.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"12"},"leftText":"<p>Add this information to your organizer.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"marker\">What does the author think about this topic?</span></td><td><span class=\"marker\">The author believes that we should start teaching music in the schools again.</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Organizerwithtopic-opinion.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=yes,width=800,left=100,height=720,top=50'); return false;\">View the complete Op-Ed organizer <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">(opens in a new window)</span></a>&nbsp;</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"13"},"leftText":"<p>You used the active reading strategy of questioning to identify the topic and what the author believes about the topic<em>.</em><br /><br />Together, the topic and what the author thinks are the main idea of the Op-Ed.<br /><br />In this Op-Ed, you found the information about the main idea in the first two paragraphs.&nbsp; In some cases, you might find the main idea much later in the article.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td>What is it about?&nbsp; What is the topic?</td><td>Music programs in schools have been cut.</td></tr><tr><td>What does the author think about this topic?</td><td>The author believes that we should start teaching music in the schools again.</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Organizerwithtopic-opinion.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=yes,width=800,left=100,height=720,top=50'); return false;\">View the complete Op-Ed organizer <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">(opens in a new window)</span></a>&nbsp;</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"14"},"leftText":"<p>Your next step is to identify the <strong>support.</strong><br /><br /><strong>Support</strong> is the information that effective writers include to prove, explain, or describe their main ideas.<br /><br />Effective readers know how to identify support and use it to understand what they are reading.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Identifying support"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"15"},"leftText":"<p>To identify the support, use the active reading strategy of questioning.&nbsp; Ask yourself, <em>What information does the author include that proves to the audience that his ideas are right?</em><br /><br />When you have identified and made sure you understand the author&#39;s support, you will add the main points to the organizer.&nbsp; You will not include the details.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td>&nbsp;...</td><td>&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td>What evidence does the author give?</td><td>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td>...</td><td>&nbsp;</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br />View the complete Op-Ed organizer</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"16"},"leftText":"<p>Start by asking, <em>How has the author organized his support? </em><br /><br />When you previewed the Op-Ed, you noticed that the author began each new paragraph with a statement in bold type.&nbsp;<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\"> For example, the first sentence of the second paragraph is &quot;Time on learning, deciding what&#39;s important.&quot;</span><br /><br />Each bold heading gives the <strong>main idea</strong> of the paragraph.&nbsp; The main idea of the paragraph is a point of support for the main idea of the Op-Ed.&nbsp; The rest of the paragraph gives additional details.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"marker\"><strong>. . .</strong><strong>Time on learning&mdash;deciding what&rsquo;s important.</strong>&nbsp; </span>All these programs have been cut or reduced due to policies that demand more time and focus on academic areas.&nbsp; Students have six hours in a school day, and those in control of those six hours have dictated that academics rule.&nbsp; What about those students who thirst for music?&nbsp; As John Lennon said, &ldquo;Music is everybody&rsquo;s possession.&rdquo;&nbsp; Let&rsquo;s return to sharing that valuable possession.&nbsp; Reinstatement of music programs in our city will bring countless benefits to the children in our community. . .</p></td></tr></tbody></table>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"17"},"leftText":"<p>You look at the bold heading of the <em>Time on learning</em>&nbsp; paragraph to find the main idea of this paragraph.<br /><br />The meaning of this heading is not very clear.&nbsp; In this case, you need to read more of the paragraph to find out what the author means.<br /><br />The next two sentences tell you that a decision was made to focus the limited amount of time that kids spend in school on academics.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">The heading says:</span></p><p>Time on learning--deciding what&rsquo;s important<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">What this means:</span></p><p>A decision was made that time on learning is better spent on academics than music.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"18"},"leftText":"<p>Now that you know the paragraph&#39;s main idea, you can identify the additional details.<br /><br />Ask yourself, <em>What are the results of this decision?</em><br /><br />The details in the paragraph help answer your question.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Main idea of the paragraph: </span></p><p>A decision was made that time on learning is better spent on academics than music.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Additional details:</span></p><p>programs have been cut<br />focus on academics<br />academics rule<br />let&#39;s bring back music<br />music brings benefits</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"19"},"leftText":"<p>In the next paragraph from the Op-Ed, the bold heading identifies the main idea more clearly.&nbsp; <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">It is &quot;Participation in an instrumental music program keeps kids busy and committed.&quot;</span><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"marker\"><strong>. . .Participation in an instrumental music program keeps kids busy and committed.</strong>&nbsp;</span> A well-run band program requires a time commitment of its participants.&nbsp; Students need time to take lessons, practice, perform, and compete.&nbsp; All these time commitments keep our youth busy and out of trouble.&nbsp; In the words of <em>The Music</em> <em>Man, </em>&ldquo;Idle hands are the devil&rsquo;s workshop.&rdquo;&nbsp; Kids with nothing to do are more likely to engage in negative behaviors than those who fill their after-school hours with music. . .</p></td></tr></tbody></table>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"20"},"leftText":"<p>You see that the author has clearly stated the main idea of this paragraph and has put it in bold type.&nbsp; Music keeps kids busy.<br /><br />Ask yourself, <em>How does it help kids to be busy?</em><br /><br />The details in the paragraph help answer your question.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Main idea of the paragraph: </span></p><p>Music keeps kids busy.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Additional details:</span></p><p>Participating in a music program involves a time commitment.</p><p>When kids are busy, they stay out of trouble.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"21"},"leftText":"<p>Some readers like to make an <strong>outline</strong> to organize main ideas and details.&nbsp; This helps you make sure that you have identified the main idea correctly, and understand and remember what you are reading.</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Organizing ideas in an outline"},{"settings":{"showAudio":0,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0},"leftText":"<p>You look at another paragraph from the Op-Ed.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><strong>. . .Making music is a team effort.</strong>&nbsp; Some community members have suggested that sports and music are in competition in our community.&nbsp; They suggest that sports promote a team spirit and mentality.&nbsp; Music makers also participate in a team.&nbsp; A single musician discovers new possibilities when he or she joins an orchestra, band, or chorus, lending a solitary tune to a group production and creating a whole that is bigger than the sum of its parts. . .</td></tr></tbody></table>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"22"},"leftText":"<p>You can organize the main idea and details in an outline showing the main idea as the (A) heading, and the details indented in a numbered list underneath.<br /><br /><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/picture_it.png\" /> <a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Pictureit_Outlining.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=yes,width=826,left=100,height=800,top=0'); return false;\">Organizing ideas in an outline: Picture it!</a>&nbsp; <a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Screen_reader_picture_it_organizing_ideas_in_an_outline.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/accessible_icon.png\" style=\"width: 17px; height: 20px;\" /><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">Screen reader version of Organizing ideas in an outline, opens in a new tab</span></a><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Organizing ideas in an outline:</span></p><p>A. Music requires teamwork</p><ol><li>Some people say that sports are more important than music because sports promote teamwork.</li><li>Music encourages teamwork.</li><li>Musicians work together to produce a group effort.</li></ol>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"23"},"leftText":"<p>You can continue to use the bold headings and the technique of questioning to identify the main ideas or points of support in the remaining paragraphs of the Op-Ed.<br /><br />When you are done, add these to the organizer in the section for the question <em>What support does the author use to prove his ideas?</em>&nbsp; Do not add the details.<br />&nbsp;</p><p><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/picture_it.png\" style=\"width: 27px; height: 27px;\" />&nbsp; <a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Pictureit_Extractingkeyideas.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=yes,width=826,left=100,height=750,top=50'); return false;\">Extracting key ideas and details: Picture it!</a>&nbsp; <a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Screen_reader_picture_it_extracting_key_ideas.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/accessible_icon.png\" style=\"width: 17px; height: 20px;\" /><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">Screen reader version of Extracting key ideas and details, opens in a new tab</span></a><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"font-size: 13px; width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"marker\">What support does the author use to prove his ideas?</span></td><td><p style=\"font-size:13px;\"><span class=\"marker\">A decision was made that time on learning is better spent on academics than music.</span></p><p style=\"font-size:13px;\"><span class=\"marker\">Participation in music keeps kids busy.</span></p><p style=\"font-size:13px;\"><span class=\"marker\">Music requires teamwork.</span></p><p style=\"font-size:13px;\"><span class=\"marker\">Music allows for failure.</span></p><p style=\"font-size:13px;\"><span class=\"marker\">Learning music helps kids learn other subjects.</span></p><p style=\"font-size:13px;\"><span class=\"marker\">Some kids stay in school because of music.</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/2/Organizerwithsupport.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=yes,width=800,left=100,height=720,top=50'); return false;\">View the complete Op-Ed organizer <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">(opens in a new window)</span></a>&nbsp;</p>","headerText":"Adding to the organizer"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"24"},"leftText":"<p>Many times, a piece of writing will not include bold headings. Then you, as the reader, should look for the <strong>topic sentence </strong>in each paragraph.<br /><br />The topic sentence is usually the first sentence in the paragraph.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><img alt=\"A diagram shows the two parts of a paragraph.   The first part is the topic sentence.   The second part is the details that support the topic sentence.  The second part usually has several sentences.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p>","headerText":"Using topic sentences to identify support"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"25"},"leftText":"<p>In the paragraph on the right, the topic sentence, although not bold, serves the same purpose as a heading.<br /><br />Read it, and ask yourself, <em>How could music help kids learn about geography?</em><br /><br />The details in the paragraph help answer your question.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"marker\">When kids learn about music in schools, they also learn geography.</span>&nbsp;<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">This is the topic sentence.&nbsp;</span> The music we hear every day finds its rhythm in lots of other cultures, such as&nbsp; European, African, and Latin American. When kids stop and listen to the lyrics, they absorb words from other languages and dialects.</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Main idea:</span></p><p>Music teaches kids about geography.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Additional details:</span></p><p>They hear rhythms from other cultures.<br />They learn words from other languages.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"26"},"leftText":"<p>At other times, a writer may use more than one paragraph to fully discuss one idea.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p>If we listen to the lyrics of American protest music of the 1960s, we learn a lot about that period in American history. The words to songs from that decade tell us what people cared about--civil rights, equal opportunities, and bringing about change. Young people all over the country united to sing out against the Vietnam War.</p><p>Different types of music had a similar message about peace and solidarity.&nbsp;&nbsp; Musicians shared their opinions, and used the popularity of their music as a catalyst for change. Kids studying protest music in school now can learn about how those with a voice can speak for those who are not always heard.</p></td></tr></tbody></table>","headerText":"Finding support when the same idea is discussed in more than one paragraph"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"27"},"leftText":"<p>The main idea will most likely appear in the first paragraph, but the details will be in two paragraphs.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Main idea: </span></p><p>Music teaches kids about history.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Additional details from both paragraphs:</span></p><p>Studying the music of the 1960s teaches about a time of protest.<br />Kids learn what was important to people in the 1960s.<br />Kids learn that musicians can speak up for others.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"28"},"leftText":"<p>When an idea is discussed in one or more paragraphs, only the first paragraph may have a topic sentence.&nbsp;<br /><br />When you read a paragraph without a topic sentence, ask yourself <em>Do the ideas in this paragraph support the ideas and topic in the previous paragraph?&quot;</em><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Second paragraph has no topic sentence:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p>. . .Young people all over the country united to sing out against the Vietnam War.</p><p>Different types of music had a similar message about peace and solidarity.&nbsp;&nbsp; Musicians shared their opinions, and used the popularity of their music as a catalyst for change. Kids studying protest music in school now can learn about how those with a voice can speak for those who are not always heard.</p></td></tr></tbody></table>","headerText":"Paragraphs that don't have topic sentences"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"29"},"rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Paragraph with no topic sentence:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p>My friends were all there with empty boxes, trash bags, and packing tape. My brother arrived with his truck, bringing his two roommates to help load my furniture into the truck. Fortunately, the weather was perfect, not too hot with no rain all day.</p></td></tr></tbody></table>","leftText":"<p>In other cases, a writer may not have followed the practice of starting a paragraph with a topic sentence.&nbsp;<br /><br />To identify the topic of the paragraph, ask yourself <em>What is the author trying to say?&nbsp; Is there a single idea that this information proves, shows, or describes?</em><br />&nbsp;</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"30"},"leftText":"<p>In this paragraph, all the sentences relate to and support the idea of a moving day that has gone smoothly.&nbsp; <em>Moving day</em> is the topic.&nbsp;&nbsp; The main idea is<em> Moving day went smoothly.</em><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Main idea:</span></p><p>Moving day went smoothly.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Additional details:</span></p><p>Friends came to help.<br />We had plenty of supplies.<br />My brother brought his truck.<br />The weather was perfect.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"31"},"leftText":"<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-summary\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\">Remember!&nbsp; The main idea<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">&nbsp;,</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><p>To identify the<strong> main idea,</strong> ask yourself</p><ul><li>what is this all about?</li><li>what does the author think about this?</li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Putting it all style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">&nbsp;,</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><ul><li>Look for the author&#39;s organization.</li><li>Use questioning to find main ideas and additional details for each paragraph or groups of paragraphs.</li><li>Make an outline to organize the main ideas and details</li><li>Include the author&#39;s main ideas for each paragraph in the organizer.&nbsp; Do not include the details.</li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":0,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0},"leftText":"<p>Here Schwinkle</td></tr><tr><td>Why is the author writing?</td><td>He wants to convince readers that music should be taught in schools.<br /><br />He also wants people to come to an information session.</td></tr><tr><td>Who will read the Op-Ed?</td><td>Residents of your town</td></tr><tr><td>What is it about?<br />What is the topic?</td><td>Music programs in the schools have been cut.</td></tr><tr><td>What does the author think about this topic?</td><td><p>The author believes that we should start teaching music in the schools again.</p></td></tr><tr><td>What support does the author use to prove his ideas?</td><td><p>A decision was made that time on learning is better spent on academics than music.<br /><br />Participation in music keeps kids busy and out of trouble.<br /><br />Music requires teamwork.<br /><br />Music allows for failure.<br /><br />Learning music helps kids learn other subjects.<br /><br />Some kids stay in school because of in</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Op-Ed organizer</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td>What is the title of the Op-Ed?</td><td><p><strong>Town Music Shop Blows the Horn on Needed Music Education</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td>Who is the author of the Op-Ed?</td><td>Henry Schwinkle</td></tr><tr><td>Why is the author writing the Op-Ed?</td><td>He wants to convince readers that music should be taught in schools.</td></tr><tr><td>Who will read the Op-Ed?</td><td>Residents of your town</td></tr><tr><td>What is the Op--Ed about?</td><td>A small girl, Tina Tully, stole and used several musical instruments over a period of several days. When she was caught, she told police she wanted to play an instrument, but was not given any opportunity to do this in the local schools.</td></tr><tr><td>What does the author think about this topic?</td><td>The author believes that Tina Tully stole the musical instruments because she could not learn to play an instrument in her school. He also believes that music should be taught in schools.</td></tr><tr><td>What evidence does the author use to prove his ideas</td><td><p>Music program was cut to give more time to academics.</p><p>Participation in music keeps kids busy.</p><p>Music helps kids understand the learning process.</p><p>Music requires teamwork.</p><p>Learning music helps kids learn other subjects.</p><p>&nbsp;Some kids stay in school because of music. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p></td></tr><tr><td>How does the author conclude or end the Op-Ed?</td><td>&nbsp;</td></tr></tbody></table>"}],"overviewHeader":"Overview"}
